<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_socket_noninheritable_:
```c
int
MHD_socket_noninheritable_ (MHD_socket sock)
{
#if defined(MHD_POSIX_SOCKETS)
  int flags;

  flags = fcntl (sock,
                 F_GETFD);
  if (-1 == flags)
    return 0;

  if ( ((flags | FD_CLOEXEC) != flags) &&
       (0 != fcntl (sock,
                    F_SETFD,
                    flags | FD_CLOEXEC)) )
    return 0;
#elif defined(MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS)
  if (! SetHandleInformation ((HANDLE) sock,
                              HANDLE_FLAG_INHERIT,
                              0))
    return 0;
#endif /* MHD_WINSOCK_SOCKETS */
  return ! 0;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if ( ((flags | FD_CLOEXEC) != flags) &&
       (0 != fcntl (sock,
                    F_SETFD,
                    flags | FD_CLOEXEC)) )
    return 0;
explanation: Rule 8.13 concerns pointer types and their const-qualification. The listed fragments involve the function parameter MHD_socket sock and its uses (passed to fcntl and cast to HANDLE for SetHandleInformation) — these are the places to inspect to determine whether the parameter is a pointer type and, if so, whether it could/should be const-qualified. Other parts of the function (local int flags, bitwise checks, return expressions, preprocessor conditionals) do not declare or manipulate pointer types and therefore are not relevant to Rule 8.13 and need not be investigated.
